title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?

explanation: This claim suggests a temporal change in the effect of having children on life satisfaction and links it to fertility rates, contributing a new perspective.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?

explanation: This statement differentiates between life satisfaction and happiness, providing a nuanced understanding of the effects of having children.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?
claim: Overall, our results are in tandem with the old-age support argument that having children brings utility to parents, particularly parents who are more advanced in years.
explanation: This claim aligns with the old-age support argument, offering evidence that having children benefits older parents, thus contributing to the literature.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?
claim: We also find that the happiness and life satisfaction effect of having children has been substantially diluted over time which can explain the drop in fertility rates in Europe.
explanation: This statement provides a novel explanation for the decline in fertility rates, linking it to changes in the perceived benefits of having children.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?

explanation: This claim highlights the differential impact of family policies on the decision to have children versus the number of children, offering new insights into policy effectiveness.

title: Chapter 4

title: Chapter 4

title: State Of The Art Falling Fertility Rates: New Challenges To The European Welfare State
claim: I argue that an actor-centred approach to the study of family policy developments within welfare regimes is most appropriate, rather than subscribing to the functionalist theory of industrialization, which posits that the onset of industrialization changed the structure of society and in turn created new social problems.
explanation: This statement presents a novel perspective by advocating for an actor-centred approach over the traditional functionalist theory, suggesting a new way to study family policy developments.

claim: The analysis of the collected data shows that there are many features of post-modernity functioning in the consciousness of the interviewed men who decide not to have children which are manifested at different levels of social life.
explanation: This statement claims a novel finding from the author's research about the influence of post-modernity on men's decision to remain childless.

claim: The analysis of the collected data made it possible to identify three categories/types of voluntarily childless men: 1) those who postpone their decision about parenthood; 2) those who, in a way, fall into the first identified category, namely, they postpone their decision but they are not the ones who ultimately make the decision; they agree not to have any offspring ('if my wife decides to have a child, we will, if not, we will be childless'), they currently have a neutral attitude towards having offspring; 3) those who have made up their mind/ are strongly committed to not having any offspring.
explanation: This statement presents a novel categorization of voluntarily childless men based on the author's research findings.

claim: The analysis of collected data has shown that we are dealing with a conglomerate of factors influencing the phenomenon in question.
explanation: This statement claims a novel finding that multiple factors influence the decision to remain childless, based on the author's research.

claim: Voluntary childlessness can be interpreted in terms of post-modern changes in values, cultural norms, changes in cultural concepts of gender, as well as economic changes and changes in work organisation.
explanation: This statement claims a novel interpretation of voluntary childlessness as influenced by post-modern changes, based on the author's research.

claim: The identified set of reasons which determine the postponement of fatherhood or giving up on having children allows for the identification of three strands in the male narrative of voluntary childlessness.
explanation: This statement claims a novel identification of three narrative strands in the context of voluntary childlessness, based on the author's research.

title: A Research Note On The Convergence Of Childlessness Rates Between Women With Secondary And Tertiary Education In The United States
claim: Our fndings indicate that the rates of childlessness for women aged 40–44 with tertiary education in the United States are the lowest they have been in over three decades and that rates of childlessness are converging among women with secondary and tertiary education.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a novel finding about the convergence of childlessness rates among women with different educational levels in the United States, which contributes new knowledge to the field.

title: A Research Note On The Convergence Of Childlessness Rates Between Women With Secondary And Tertiary Education In The United States
claim: The declines in childlessness rates and the convergence in childlessness rates between women with secondary and tertiary education are observed for all of the three largest race/ethnicity sub-populations of American women: non-Hispanic white, non-Hispanic black, and Hispanic women.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it highlights a specific trend observed across major racial/ethnic groups, adding a new dimension to the understanding of childlessness trends in the U.S.

title: A Research Note On The Convergence Of Childlessness Rates Between Women With Secondary And Tertiary Education In The United States
claim: In contrast to historical trends of diverging rates of permanent childlessness among women with high and low/medium education in the United States, in this research note we document a new emerging phenomenon—a convergence of childlessness rates between women with medium and high education in the twenty-frst century.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it identifies a new trend of convergence in childlessness rates, which contrasts with previously established patterns, thus contributing new insights to the field.

title: A Research Note On The Convergence Of Childlessness Rates Between Women With Secondary And Tertiary Education In The United States
claim: This convergence in childlessness rates across educational subgroups is driven by marked declines in childlessness among women with high education, for whom the rates of childlessness in 2016 were the lowest in over three decades, at 18.8%.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it provides a specific finding about the decline in childlessness rates among highly educated women, which is a key factor in the observed convergence.

title: Education, Other Socioeconomic Characteristics Across The Life Course, And Fertility Among Finnish Men
claim: In men, education is positively associated with eventual fertility after controlling for early socioeconomic and other characteristics shared by brothers.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a novel finding about the positive association between education and fertility in men, even after controlling for certain variables.

title: Education, Other Socioeconomic Characteristics Across The Life Course, And Fertility Among Finnish Men
claim: Selective entry into fatherhood based on economic provider potential may contribute considerably to educational differentials in the number of children among men.
explanation: This statement is a claim as it suggests a new perspective on how economic potential influences educational differences in fertility.

title: Education, Other Socioeconomic Characteristics Across The Life Course, And Fertility Among Finnish Men
claim: The study takes the previous literature further by showing that socioeconomic advantage across the life course associates with male fertility: among Finnish men born between 1940 and 1950, lower numbers of children were found among men from socioeconomically less-advantaged families and among those with a lower educational level, occupational position, and income level.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it extends previous research by demonstrating a specific association between socioeconomic advantage and fertility in Finnish men.

title: Education, Other Socioeconomic Characteristics Across The Life Course, And Fertility Among Finnish Men
claim: A novel finding was that the educational gradient in fertility in men was neither explained by early-life socioeconomic nor by other characteristics shared by brothers.
explanation: This statement is a claim as it presents a new finding that challenges previous assumptions about the factors explaining educational gradients in fertility.

title: Education, Other Socioeconomic Characteristics Across The Life Course, And Fertility Among Finnish Men
claim: Men's occupational position and income mediated approximately half of the association between education and the number of children.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it identifies a specific mediating role of occupational position and income in the relationship between education and fertility.

title: Perpetual Postponers? Women'S, Men'S And Couple'S Fertility Intentions And Subsequent Fertility Behaviour
claim: At the aggregate level, data from the British Household Panel Survey (BHPS) suggest that men's and women's fertility intentions are consistent. No evidence is found that men intend to have smaller families than women.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a novel finding from the study, indicating that there is no significant difference between men's and women's fertility intentions in terms of family size.

title: Perpetual Postponers? Women'S, Men'S And Couple'S Fertility Intentions And Subsequent Fertility Behaviour
claim: Within couples there is considerable consistency in the reported future intended fertility.
explanation: This statement is a claim as it highlights a new observation about the consistency of fertility intentions within couples, contributing to the understanding of couple dynamics in fertility planning.

title: Perpetual Postponers? Women'S, Men'S And Couple'S Fertility Intentions And Subsequent Fertility Behaviour
claim: Conflicting responses are more likely when the woman already has two or more children and intends to have a further birth. In such cases almost half of the men were either uncertain or did not intend to have another child.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it identifies a specific situation where discrepancies in fertility intentions are more prevalent, providing insight into family planning challenges.

title: Perpetual Postponers? Women'S, Men'S And Couple'S Fertility Intentions And Subsequent Fertility Behaviour
claim: Prospective individual level data from the BHPS show that women overestimate their future fertility.
explanation: This statement is a claim as it presents a finding that women tend to overestimate their fertility, which is a significant insight into fertility intention accuracy.

title: Perpetual Postponers? Women'S, Men'S And Couple'S Fertility Intentions And Subsequent Fertility Behaviour
claim: Of the childless women aged in their thirties who intended to start a family only around one half managed to do so in the subsequent six years.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it provides a specific statistic about the success rate of childless women in their thirties who intended to start a family, offering new data on fertility outcomes.

title: Perpetual Postponers? Women'S, Men'S And Couple'S Fertility Intentions And Subsequent Fertility Behaviour
claim: Whilst the fertility intentions of older childless women do not seem to be affected by whether they are currently in a partnership, having a partner is a key factor affecting the likelihood that the woman will have a child.
explanation: This statement is a claim as it distinguishes between the influence of partnership status on fertility intentions versus actual childbearing, contributing to the understanding of factors influencing fertility.

title: Perpetual Postponers? Women'S, Men'S And Couple'S Fertility Intentions And Subsequent Fertility Behaviour
claim: Starting a family when aged in their thirties is more common among women in the highest earnings quartile.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it identifies a socioeconomic factor (earnings quartile) that correlates with the likelihood of starting a family in one's thirties, providing insight into economic influences on fertility behavior.

title: Sociocultural Determinants Of Infertility Stress In Patients Undergoing Fertility Treatments
claim: The results of this study suggest that in both men and women, low spousal support predicts infertility stress.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a novel finding from the study, indicating a specific relationship between spousal support and infertility stress.

title: Sociocultural Determinants Of Infertility Stress In Patients Undergoing Fertility Treatments
claim: Data from this study also suggests that financial constraints significantly predict stress in men and women taking fertility treatment.
explanation: This statement is a claim as it identifies a specific predictor of stress related to infertility treatments, contributing new knowledge to the field.

title: Sociocultural Determinants Of Infertility Stress In Patients Undergoing Fertility Treatments

explanation: This statement is a claim because it highlights a specific sociocultural factor contributing to infertility stress, which is a novel finding of the study.

title: Sociocultural Determinants Of Infertility Stress In Patients Undergoing Fertility Treatments

explanation: This statement is a claim as it identifies a specific sociocultural factor (family stigma and discrimination) that predicts distress in infertile men, contributing new insights to the field.

title: Sociocultural Determinants Of Infertility Stress In Patients Undergoing Fertility Treatments

explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a novel finding about the impact of family overinvolvement on distress in women facing fertility problems.

title: Sociocultural Determinants Of Infertility Stress In Patients Undergoing Fertility Treatments
claim: Intriguingly, the data from this study revealed that peer support neither predicts nor protects against infertility distress experienced by men and women.
explanation: This statement is a claim as it provides a novel insight into the role of peer support in infertility distress, which is contrary to common assumptions.

title: Abstract
claim: This application contributes to research on unintended childbearing by addressing measurement concerns over couples' intentions, developing a theoretical framework to assess gender and disagreement in couples' intentions, and predicting couples' fertility intentions.
explanation: The claim highlights the paper's novel contribution to the field by addressing measurement concerns and developing a new theoretical framework.

title: Abstract
claim: Based on a family systems perspective, I assert that unintended fertility cannot merely be viewed as a social problem involving and affecting mothers and children.
explanation: The claim introduces a new perspective by asserting that unintended fertility should be viewed as a couple-level issue, not just an individual one.

title: Abstract
claim: Conceptualizing intentions as a couple-level phenomenon provides a holistic, nuanced framework to better understand both the factors that influence fertility intentions and the effects intentions have on parents and children.
explanation: The claim suggests a novel framework for understanding fertility intentions at the couple level, which is a new approach in the field.

explanation: The claim points out a gap in existing research due to data limitations, emphasizing the overlooked role of fathers' intentions.

claim: The second set of analyses predict couple-level fertility intentions: both intended, only mother intended, only father intended, and neither intended.

claim: I expect mothers who are married to the biological father provide more consistent reports on fathers' intentions than their unwed counterparts.

claim: Couples' intentions clearly have implications for both mothers' and fathers' well-being (which was consistent with the second application), which in turn has implications for parental involvement and child well-being.

title: Educational Attainment And Maternity In Spain: Not Only ''When'' But Also ''How''

title: Educational Attainment And Maternity In Spain: Not Only ''When'' But Also ''How''

title: Educational Attainment And Maternity In Spain: Not Only ''When'' But Also ''How''

title: Educational Attainment And Maternity In Spain: Not Only ''When'' But Also ''How''

title: Chapter 3 Childlessness In The Uk

claim: We can argue that lockdowns have more clearly highlighted critical aspects of these transnational practices and that they have radically changed the obstacles that Italian gay men are forced to face.

title: Stuck Under The Rainbow? Gay Parents' Experiences With Transnational Surrogacy And Family
claim: In this unexpected crisis, parents confined to Italy considered extended networks of support to be very useful and supportive resources.

title: Stuck Under The Rainbow? Gay Parents' Experiences With Transnational Surrogacy And Family
claim: The extraordinary circumstances that we have analysed have made it even more evident that not only is reproduction separate from sexuality, but that filiation and parenthood nowadays involve more people and enlarged caring relations.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it provides a novel perspective on how modern parenthood and family formation involve broader social networks, separating reproduction from traditional sexual and familial roles.

title: Stuck Under The Rainbow? Gay Parents' Experiences With Transnational Surrogacy And Family
claim: The experience of the fathers interviewed in the research makes it clear that being homosexual parents in contemporary Italy still represents an enormous challenge, which begins even before children are conceived.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it highlights the ongoing challenges faced by homosexual parents in Italy, emphasizing the difficulties that arise even before the conception of children.

title: Stuck Under The Rainbow? Gay Parents' Experiences With Transnational Surrogacy And Family
claim: Thus, what we learn from our findings is that the pandemic has further stressed transnational surrogacy and family formation practices, offering the possibility of opening a debate and space for sociological reflection on the rights of parents and children who become a family by means of such practices.

title: Table Of Contents
claim: Our findings on period parity-specific fertility in Austria lead to three main conclusions. This signals that a stabilisation of completed fertility and cohort parity distribution can be expected for women born in the late 1960s and in the 1970s. title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary
claim: The greatest obstacle standing in the way of having children is presumably the lack of a stable partner relationship.

claim: Our results are consistent with those of Spéder and Kapitány [2014] regarding Hungary: they found that in a European comparison the chances of realising childbearing intentions are significantly lower in Central and Eastern European post-communist countries than in Western Europe.
explanation: This statement presents a comparative finding about the realization of childbearing intentions in different European regions, adding to the existing literature.

explanation: This claim challenges common assumptions about the reasons for unrealized fertility intentions, suggesting that neither changing values nor economic factors are primary causes in Hungary.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary

explanation: This statement outlines the novel methodological approach used in the study, which combines multiple theoretical frameworks to analyze childlessness.

title: The Influence Of Income And Work Hours On First Birth For Australian Women
claim: This study examines the influence of labour income and work hours on the timing of first birth for Australian women. explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a novel finding about the influence of labour income and work hours on the timing of first birth for Australian women, indicating that both factors have an impact and that the effect of income changes when work hours are considered.

title: The Influence Of Income And Work Hours On First Birth For Australian Women
claim: In the current study, the relationship between higher gross weekly incomes and first birth depends on the age of the woman. Higher gross weekly incomes are associated with a higher risk of first birth from around the age of 30.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it introduces a new understanding of how the relationship between income and first birth risk is age-dependent, specifically highlighting that higher incomes increase the risk of first birth after age 30.

title: The Influence Of Income And Work Hours On First Birth For Australian Women
claim: In this study, the level of employment remains a statistically significant associate of first birth risks after controlling for income, and this relationship is not dependent on age of the woman.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it provides a new insight into the relationship between employment level and first birth risks, showing that employment level is a significant factor independent of age.

title: The Influence Of Income And Work Hours On First Birth For Australian Women
claim: Working part-time, around 3 days per week, increases the risk of first birth relative to working shorter part-time hours or full-time or longer.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a specific finding about how part-time work influences the risk of first birth, contributing new knowledge to the field.

title: Motherhood In Spain: From The "Baby Boom" To "Structural Infertility"
claim: We have shown how motherhood is governed in Spain through four moral regimes surrounding a) the labor market, b) gender relations at home, c) institutional feminist discourses and d) the narrative of choice.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it presents a novel framework for understanding how motherhood is governed in Spain, contributing new knowledge to the field by identifying four specific moral regimes.

title: Motherhood In Spain: From The "Baby Boom" To "Structural Infertility"
claim: In short, by examining these four moral regimes, we can see how Spain went from a "baby boom" to "structural infertility" in such a short time span: under changing social circumstances, women are no longer able to shoulder the responsibility for reproduction alone.
explanation: This statement is a claim because it interprets the impact of the identified moral regimes on the demographic shift in Spain, offering a new perspective on the transition from high fertility to structural infertility.
